Award.AwardTitle: GP-EXTRA: Using professional career experiences to strengthen pathways into the geoscience workforce
Award.AbstractNarration:
The predicted national shortfall of 135,000 geoscientists by 2022 will have major consequences for the provision of energy and water resources and the quality of the environment, necessities that sustain a strong economy and ensure the health and welfare of all Americans. This project is addressing the personnel shortfall by testing a comprehensive program of career-related extracurricular activities that aims to improve retention and achievement levels of students earning four-year college degrees in the geosciences and increase the number and diversity of these skilled scientists that succeed in the workforce after graduation. The best practices defined from evaluating the success of the program are being used to build a model that can be followed by other universities.

The project is examining the effect of experiential learning opportunities on higher student retention rates in the geosciences, improvement in academic performance, and successful career placement. A diverse group of 18 undergraduate geology majors at the University of Texas at San Antonio (a Minority-Serving and Hispanic-Serving Institution) are engaging in a sequence of three internships in different geoscience fields to provide multiple career-related work experiences. Each student is completing an academic internship involving research and teaching activities on campus, followed by two placements in the energy resources, geo-environmental assessment, and water resources fields. The four career trajectories have clear pathways into the local employment market through private companies and governmental agencies. Students are also participating in a suite of academic and professional workshops to enhance competencies and skills in preparation for their careers. A multi-level mentoring strategy that promotes personal and professional growth and an integrated scheme of networking opportunities aims to smooth the transition into the geoscience workforce. Program activities are being assessed through a systematic plan of surveys, interviews, and external reviews. The project seeks to improve undergraduate education to address the projected shortfall in geoscientists, promote the participation of underrepresented groups in both geoscience majors and careers, and contribute to research on strengthening partnerships between higher education institutions and external geoscience organizations. The project will increase the number and diversity of skilled workers entering the geoscience workforce and lead to best practice strategies that can be implemented at other universities to impact meaningfully on the retention, education, and career trajectories of geoscience majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To address the projected shortage of trained geoscientists in the United States, the Geoscience Pathways Program at the Minority-Serving and Hispanic-Serving University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) engaged with 38 undergraduate geology majors between 2016 and 2019 to promote their retention in the major and facilitate their transition into the geoscience workforce. In contrast to most student-centered extracurricular programs, we targeted students with potential whose academic performance was currently below the highest range of grade point averages as a means to augment numbers of trained geoscientists, and invited this group of students to participate in program activities. We designed and implemented four core activities that consisted of semester-long authentic work experiences (experiential learning) in one or more career tracks (76 internships in total), mentoring by geoscience professors and industry partners (76 mentoring relationships), professional development activities covering technical and soft skills (43 workshops and short courses), and social networking events (17 functions). Adapting a medical school clinical rotation model, three cohorts of juniors were recruited and initially placed in internships in research laboratories at UTSA. A subset of these participants subsequently engaged in additional internships at local private companies, non-profit organizations, and government agencies related to energy resources, environmental geology, and water resources. The effectiveness of program activities and engagement by student participants were evaluated using multiple surveys and focus group interviews and university records.

Our analyses yielded two new insights that can inform the development of effective practices to recruit and retain diverse students in geoscience postsecondary education (including graduate education) and the geoscience workforce. First, a clinical rotation-type model for authentic work experiences significantly expands career knowledge and helps focus geology majors toward the career trajectories they are most interested in. Students experienced continued growth in their motivation for and interest in pursuing a geoscience career with each subsequent semester in the program. These students also grew more career ready because they acquired greater knowledge about a wider range of career options. Further, authentic work experiences in a specific career track led to increased interest in that track for the vast majority of the participants, even if that track was not their top-ranked preference at the beginning of the program. Second, as an alternative strategy to requiring applications for acceptance into student-centered programs, this program devised and implemented an invitational approach that identified students who met the selection criteria for the program. Subsequently, program directors reached out personally to these students individually to meet with them and explain specific details about and benefits of the program. This process resulted in a group of participants that reflected the full diversity of the geology majors at the institution, and thus will help to grow a more diverse geoscience workforce. This strategy aids in resolving a regrettably common occurrence of students who are first generation college goers and/or from underrepresented groups opting not to pursue co-curricular or extracurricular program opportunities that can lead to professional and personal growth and increased competitiveness in the job market. Adopting this invitational approach has the potential to significantly increase the diversity of trained geoscientists, and if applied to programs in other STEM disciplines, could extend the impact to the wider technical workforce.

The broader impacts of the program are two-fold. First, it has promoted the career prospects of students from historically underrepresented groups in the geosciences, including Hispanics and women who represent large proportions of the population. To date, 30 participants (80%) have graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in geology. Further, results indicate that program participants from this Hispanic-Serving Institution gained confidence in their ability to compete for graduate school opportunities and job positions that they might otherwise have not applied to. Second, about 25% of program participants have already pursued graduate level education to gain additional credentials. Transition to the geoscience workforce by participants is documented by their employment in geoscience education, energy resources, and environmental geology job positions. Some of these transitions were the direct result of the internship experiences created by the program. The project also supported the development of the next generation of scientists by engaging four graduate students in program operation and created new opportunities for geoscience professionals to hone their mentoring skills. So far, research results have been presented at three professional conferences and published in two journal articles. The project website is at http://www.utsa.edu/geosci/pathways/.
